start.title:
Slime Time:

Exponential Growth in Action
start.description: Discover the power of compound growth through the story of teenage entrepreneur Samantha, 16, and her 12-year-old brother Ben Ward. Watch as they analyze their slime business using mathematical principles, calculate growth rates, explore investment scenarios, and create a path to potential millions‚Äîall starting with just $20 and the magic of exponential functions.

S2_D1_FX_C0.heading: Welcome to Slime business!
S2_D1_FX_C0.body: I'm Samantha, and this is my brother Ben. We run Slime Time, a successful slime business we started with just $20 last year. Today, we're analyzing our business using mathematics. Join us as we use exponential functions to model business growth, understand debt risks, and create a path to becoming millionaires by our twenties - all through the power of compound growth!

S4_D0_FX_C9.title: Business Plan Presentation
S4_D0_FX_C9.slideOverviewIntro: This presentation covers slime varieties, growth strategies, and business opportunities.

title_slide.heading: SLIME TIME
title_slide.description: For Community Bank Small Business Loan

online_slide.heading: ONLINE EXPANSION STRATEGY
online_slide.strategyCost1: Renting a space for $500/month at farmers market
online_slide.strategyCost2: Pro video shoot equipment + studio setup $1,500
online_slide.opportunityDescription: Expand production to meet exponential customer demands
online_slide.opportunityAction: That's why we need this loan! üöÄ

S4.S4_D1_FX_C3: So let me make sure I understand. You want a business loan for... slime?
S4.S4_D2_FX_C2: This isn't just any slime. Slime Time is premium, specialized slime ‚Äî with unique textural properties.
S4.S4_D3_FX_C1: We actually produce 8 different varieties of slime. And our customers really love it.
S4.S4_D4_FX_C2: After discovering an unmet need in the market, we started selling jars of slime to our classmates for $5 a jar.
S4.S4_D5_FX_C1: In our first year, we only made $20.
S4.S4_D6_FX_C3: I'm sorry, but $20 isn't much of a business.
S4.S4_D8_FX_C1: But as you can see, over this past year, we've sold more than $2000 worth of slime!
S4.S4_D7_FX_C2: That's over 400 units ‚Äî each carefully crafted by trained artisans.
S4.S4_D9_FX_C2: Currently, the majority of our revenue comes from our stand at the farmers market. To continue our exponential growth, we've started promoting our products online.
S4.S4_D11_FX_C1: Our 'Satisfying Slime Smoosh' video now has over 12,000 views.
S4.S4_D12_FX_C2: And you see, Mr Donovan, that's why we are here for a loan. We need to scale our manufacturing process to keep up with our exponential customer demand.
S4.S4_D15_FX_C2: Don't worry, I've prepared a slide deck that shows our exponential growth model.

about.heading: Exponential Business Growth
about.body:
This interactive demonstrates how a business can grow at different rates over time. The business has two potential growth paths: Realistic (10%), and Historical (9900%).

Notice how even small changes in the growth rate lead to dramatically different outcomes! This is the power of exponential growth, where each increase builds on the previous value.

help.heading: Projecting Growth
help.body:
Adjust initial profit, growth rates, and projection years to see long-term business potential. The exponential function R(t) = R‚ÇÄ √ó (1 + g)t shows how consistent percentage growth creates dramatic results over time.

Questions to Consider:

1) What would their weekly profit be in 5 years if they maintained their historical growth rate (9900%)?

2) Which growth scenario seems most realistic for a small business long-term?

about_step3.heading: Units Reality Check
about_step3.body:
This interactive reveals the practical challenges of exponential growth by converting revenue projections into actual units that must be produced and sold.

While exponential mathematics can show impressive growth potential, real businesses face physical constraints like production capacity, storage space, market demand, and resource limitations. This step helps students understand why exponential growth typically levels off in real-world scenarios.

help_step3.heading: Realistic Growth Analysis
help_step3.body:
Use the sliders to adjust unit price and time frame to see how many jars would be needed to achieve projected revenue. This calculator helps assess whether exponential growth projections are practically achievable.

Key Calculations:

‚Ä¢ Total jars needed = Projected Revenue √∑ Unit Price

‚Ä¢ Consider production capacity, market demand, and storage limitations

‚Ä¢ Compare current growth rate (9900%) vs. realistic growth rate (10%)

Questions to Consider:

1) How many jars would they need to produce daily to meet the 9900% growth projection?

2) Is it physically possible to produce and sell 40,000 jars given their current resources?

3) What factors limit a business's ability to maintain exponential growth?

about_step4.heading: Business Parameters & Loan Analysis
about_step4.body:
This interactive demonstrates how business decisions about pricing, capacity, and investment affect financial outcomes and loan repayment ability.

Students can explore the relationship between unit economics, scale, and profitability. The model shows how businesses must balance pricing strategy with production capacity while considering fixed costs like storage space and variable costs like materials. This step illustrates why sustainable business growth requires careful financial planning beyond just revenue projections.

help_step4.heading: Business Investment Analysis
help_step4.body:
Adjust unit price and production capacity to explore how business parameters affect profitability and loan repayment ability. This model includes fixed costs, variable costs, and investment requirements.

Key Concepts:

‚Ä¢ Profit margin = Revenue - (Variable costs + Fixed costs)

‚Ä¢ Payback period = Initial investment √∑ Annual profit

‚Ä¢ Production capacity limits maximum revenue potential

Questions to Consider:

1) What unit price maximizes both profit margin and sales volume?

2) How does increasing production capacity affect the loan payback period?

3) What happens to profitability if variable costs increase due to scaling up production?

slide2.heading: Exponential Growth Formula
slide2.formulaLabel1: R of t equals R‚ÇÄ times 1 plus g to the power of t
slide2.calculationLabel: $ {initialRevenue} times 1 plus {customGrowthRate} percent to the power of {projectionYears}

S5.S5_D1_FX_C2: As you can see, we experienced massive growth this past year, from $20 to $2000. That's 100x growth!
S5.S5_D2_FX_C2: I can simply project our actual growth rate forward to show you the dizzying potential of our product.
S5.S5_D3_FX_C2: Based on this projection, by next year, we will be making $200,000 ‚Äî which is surely a 'real business' in your eyes?
S5.S5_D6_FX_C2: This is only the start. Projecting our growth over a longer timeframe would show the true scale of our potential. Let me set it to 5 years.
S5.S5_D5_FX_C3: 200 billion dollars, from slime? Come on. These numbers are‚Ä¶ hard to believe.
S5.S5_D11_FX_C2: What, you don't believe in mathematics? Here, you can try to model it yourself. It simply follows the function R(t) = R‚ÇÄ(1 + g)t, where R‚ÇÄ is initial revenue, g is growth rate, and t is time in years.
S5.S5_D10_FX_C3: Fine, let me see this formula in action. If you started with $20 and achieved a 9,900% growth rate, what would your revenue be after exactly 3 years?
S5.S5_D7_FX_C1: $20 million. The exponential function shows how our small start grew dramatically!
S5.S5_D12_FX_C1: We know that continuing the exponential growth will be difficult. But we really think there is a lot more demand!
S5.S5_D13_FX_C3: Well, if your earnings were really that high, that‚Äôs quite a bit of slime you must have moving at that pace.
S5.S5_D14_FX_C2: Yes and we could simply calculate it - just divide the total revenue by the unit cost.
S5.S5_D14_FX_C3: That does sound like simple mathematics. I think you might have the calculator setup for that too.
S5.S5_D15_FX_C1: Yes Mr. Donovan, we have that too. What values would you like us to project?
S5.S5_D15_FX_C3: Well, you said that your unit price is $5 and your growth rate is 9900%. With those figures, can you imagine how much your sales volume could grow in just 2 years?
S5.S5_D16_FX_C1: Yes, we can model that. Ben can you set the projection years to 2 years and see how many jars we have?
S5.S5_D16_FX_C3: 40,000 Jars! And you really think that every person on earth would be willing to buy different jars of your slime?
S5.S5_D17_FX_C2: That's true, we do have 8 varieties‚Ä¶
S5.S5_D18_FX_C3: That's not what I'm saying. This model is not realistic. Business growth might be fast in the beginning, but larger companies rarely have growth rates more than 10% ‚Äînot 9,900%! I see you have realistic growth projections also, toggle to that view. And now see the growth projecting for 5 years.
S5.S5_D19_FX_C1: Hmm, now it takes forever! We won't even have doubled our money.
S5.S5_D20_FX_C3: That's right. Good rule of thumb is that a 10% growth rate will approximately double your money every 7 years.
S5.S5_D21_FX_C2: But by the time that happens, I'll be way too old! All that time for just for the loan of $4,000?
S5.S5_D22_FX_C3: Well, to be honest, I do think your business has the potential to grow faster ‚Äî especially in the beginning. What do you need the loan for, anyway?
S5.S5_D23_FX_C1: Well, mostly we need to make a webshop so online customers can buy our product. It's about a $1000 investment.
S5.S5_D24_FX_C2: We also need to <no-glossary>expand</no-glossary> our manufacturing center.
S5.S5_D25_FX_C1: Yeah. Our basement's a disaster ‚Äî Mom won't let us keep anything there. So we found a storage unit for our supplies. But it costs around $2,000 for the year.
S5.S5_D26_FX_C2: If we get the storage unit, we'd finally have room to <no-glossary>expand</no-glossary>. And that's why Mr. Donovan, we need this loan.
S5.S5_D31_FX_C3: You know what, I think it's actually a good investment. You kids are very motivated ‚Äî and you've already demonstrated that people are willing to pay for your product.
S5.S5_D32_FX_C1: Does that mean we get the loan?
S5.S5_D33_FX_C3: I'm sorry, I should have told you upfront: We're a bank ‚Äî I simply can't approve a loan for applicants under 18.
S5.S5_D34_FX_C2: Can I talk with the manager?
S5.S5_D35_FX_C3: I AM the manager. But look, I think you will do great. Here's my card ‚Äî get back in touch in a few years!

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: Well, that was a waste of time.
S6.S6_D2_FX_C2: Not entirely. Mr. Donovan confirmed that our business model is sound! We simply lack the legal standing to obtain traditional financing.
S6.S6_D4_FX_C2: Why don‚Äôt we talk to Mom and see if we could use her credit card?
S6.S6_D5_FX_C1: Are you serious? First of all, Mom would never support that. But have you even considered the potential risk?
S6.S6_D6_FX_C2: What risk? I'd be very careful only to spend money on the business. And possibly carefully researched collectables.
S6.S6_D7_FX_C1: I'm talking about the interest rates. With a bank, we could have gotten an interest rate between 5-10% for our business.. But credit cards have an interest rate of nearly 30%!
S6.S6_D8_FX_C2: Not if you pay it off every month‚Äîthen it's free! Better than free‚Äîyou can get points that can be spent. It's like they are giving money away!
S6.S6_D9_FX_C1: You haven't thought this through. Let's model this.

S7_D0_FX_C9.title: Credit Card Debt Simulator

about.heading: Understanding Credit Card Debt
about.body:
While compound interest can work in your favor with investments, it works against you with debt. This simulator shows how a $3,000 business investment can grow exponentially when financed with high-interest credit cards.

Use the interactive controls to adjust the initial debt ($1,000‚Äì$10,000), interest rate (5.99%‚Äì35.99%), target debt amount ($5,000‚Äì$25,000), and minimum payment rate (1%‚Äì5%).

Each slider lets you explore different financial choices: change the Initial Debt to see how borrowing more affects the outcome, adjust the Interest Rate to simulate different lending terms, tweak the Minimum Payment to understand how small payments impact debt over time, and use the Target Payment to explore how faster payoff reduces interest.

Toggle between viewing current debt growth and total interest accumulation to see how compound interest works against borrowers.

help.heading: The Debt Trap
help.body:
Credit cards apply compound interest against you! Small purchases can become much more expensive when paid off slowly or with minimum payments.

Questions to Consider:

1) If the siblings put $3,000 on a credit card at 29.99% APR with 1% minimum payments, how many months will it take for the debt to reach $10,000?

2) How much will they still owe after 10 years of making only minimum payments?

3) How does changing the interest rate from 29.99% to a lower bank rate like 8% affect the total debt after 10 years?

S7_D0_FX_C9.inFeesAndCanDamage: in fees and can damage your credit score for up to
S7_D0_FX_C9.realityCheckMsgPt2: High interest rates make debt grow exponentially.

S7.S7_D1_FX_C1: Let's say we put $3,000 on a credit card for our business expansion. Set the debt to $3,000 and the interest rate to 24.99% - that's typical for credit cards.
S7.S7_D2_FX_C2: That doesn't seem too bad for a short-term solution...
S7.S7_D3_FX_C1: Now look what happens if we can only make minimum payments of 1% each month. The scary part is how the debt grows if we miss some payments or can't pay it down quickly.
S7.S7_D4_FX_C2: Let's try this: we set the initial debt to $3,000, the interest rate (APR) to 24.99%, minimum payment to 1% and target debt payment to $6,000. How many months will it take until our debt reaches $6,000?
S7.S7_D5_FX_C1: 65 months? That's over 5 years! And look at the total interest paid - $5,849! We'd pay almost double of what we borrowed in interest alone!
S7.S7_D6_FX_C2: Exactly! Now let's make it more realistic ‚Äî some cards charge even higher interest rates.
S7.S7_D7_FX_C1: Correct. Try this: Keep our original initial debt at $3,000 and minimum payment at 1%, but set the interest rate (APR) to 29.99%. Then check how much interest we'll end up paying by the time the debt hits $10,000.
S7.S7_D8_FX_C2: Almost $12,000 in interest for borrowing $3,000! That's almost four times what we borrowed!
S7.S7_D9_FX_C1: Compare that to Mr. Donovan's bank rates of 5-10%. At 7.99%, we'd pay maybe $1400 in interest instead of $12,000 in 81 months.
S7.S7_D10_FX_C2: Almost nine times more expensive! Credit cards are financial quicksand. No wonder successful businesses avoid high-interest debt.
S7.S7_D11_FX_C1: This is exactly why we need to find other ways to grow our business without any debt at all.

S8.S8_D1_FX_C1: Well, that credit card lesson was eye-opening! But I've been thinking - we don't need loans OR credit cards. We can grow using what we already have.
S8.S8_D3_FX_C1: Exactly! We get 12,000 views per video with a 0.5% conversion rate. That's only 60 sales per video.
S8.S8_D4_FX_C2: And we post twice weekly, so 120 sales per video from social media.
S8.S8_D5_FX_C1: But what if we improved our conversion rate to 1% AND posted daily instead of twice weekly? Let's model it

S9_D0_FX_C9.title: Social Media Growth Strategy

about.heading: Social Media Growth Strategy
about.body:
Transform your social media views into revenue through smart optimization of conversion rates and posting frequency. This interactive demonstrates how small improvements in viewer engagement can lead to exponential business growth.

Use the controls to adjust current conversion rates (0.1%-2.0%), target conversion rates (0.5%-3.0%), current videos per week (1-7), and target videos per week (1-14). Toggle between viewing weekly revenue growth and weekly sales growth to see how optimization strategies compound over time with 20% monthly growth.

help.heading: Exponential Social Media Growth
help.body:
Small changes in conversion rates and posting frequency can lead to dramatically different revenue outcomes over time.

Questions to Consider:

1) Starting with 12,000 views per video at 0.5% conversion rate posting 2 videos weekly, what happens when you improve to 1.0% conversion and 7 videos per week?

2) How does the exponential growth formula R(t) = R‚ÇÄ √ó (1 + g)·µó with 20% monthly growth affect your revenue projections over 6 months?

3) Compare the current strategy vs target strategy cards - what's the revenue multiplier effect of combined improvements?

S9_D0_FX_C9.chartAriaLabel: Interactive line chart showing 6-month revenue and sales growth projection. Use the toggle buttons above to switch between revenue and sales data views.
S9_D0_FX_C9.formulaAriaLabel: Exponential growth formula: R of t equals R naught times quantity 1 plus g quantity raised to the power of t. Where R of t is revenue after t months, R naught is initial weekly revenue, g is monthly growth rate, and t is time in years.

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: Let's try modeling a realistic growth scenario for our social media strategy. We‚Äôll use a 10% monthly growth rate ‚Äî something steady and achievable for a longer run.
S9.S9_D1_FX_C2: I'll set up the calculator with our current metrics. Current conversion rate: 0.5%, target conversion rate: 1.0%. Current videos per week: 2, target videos per week: 7. Let‚Äôs find out our targeted monthly revenue.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C2: The calculator shows our current monthly revenue is $2,400, but with the improved strategy it jumps to $16,800.
S9.S9_D3_FX_C1: That's exactly 7 times more revenue! And look at the comparison cards - current strategy gives us 60 sales per video, improved strategy gives us 120 sales per video.
S9.S9_D4_FX_C2: We used to post only 2 times a week, but now we're posting 7 times ‚Äî that‚Äôs 3.5 times more videos. And since our conversion rate is twice as good, that means we're growing about 7 times faster than before.
S9.S9_D5_FX_C1: And that's before we even factor in the monthly exponential growth! Look at month 6 - we'd be making around $30,000 monthly.
S9.S9_D6_FX_C2: The exponential growth formula shows exactly how this works. Our $16,800 monthly revenue becomes $29,820 after 6 months with 10% monthly growth.
S9.S9_D7_FX_C1: That‚Äôs the power of exponential growth‚Äîand we didn‚Äôt even spend extra money. Just better content and posting more consistently!

S10.S10_D1_FX_C1: Now that we've figured out how to grow our business organically, I've been thinking about our long-term strategy. What if we allocated a portion of our profits to investments rather than putting everything back into the business?
S10.S10_D2_FX_C2: You're suggesting portfolio diversification? Dad mentioned that in our economics project.
S10.S10_D3_FX_C1: Exactly! While our business is growing rapidly now, slime could be a passing trend. Plus, we're already working every day after school - there's a limit to how much we can <no-glossary>expand</no-glossary> right now.
S10.S10_D4_FX_C2: That's called concentration risk - having all our money in one business. What if slime suddenly becomes less popular, or a big company starts making similar products?
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: Right! So maybe we reinvest 80% back into the business and put 20% into long-term savings. Let's model some scenarios.

S11_D0_FX_C9.title: Compound Interest Calculator

info.heading: The Power of Compound Interest
info.description:
This interactive demonstrates Einstein's "eighth wonder of the world" - compound interest. The siblings are considering investing $50 weekly. The calculator shows how regular contributions grow exponentially over time.

Note how even small differences in interest rates (8% vs. 10%) result in dramatically different outcomes over long periods. The Rule of 72 helps estimate doubling time: 72 √∑ interest rate = years to double your money.

help.heading: The Power of Compound Interest
help.description:
Regular investments grow exponentially over time. See how small weekly contributions can grow to significant amounts over years or decades.

Questions to Consider:

  • If the siblings invest $50 weekly with an 8% annual return, how much will they have after 10 years?
  • How does changing the interest rate from 8% to 10% affect the final amount?
  • At what interest rate would their money double in approximately 9 years?

S11_D0_FX_C9.millionaire_description: By investing ${weeklyContribution} weekly at {annualReturn}% annual return, you'll reach {totalValue} in {years} years!
S11_D0_FX_C9.compound_interest_formula_description: A equals P times open parenthesis one plus r close parenthesis raised to the power t plus PMT times open bracket open parenthesis one plus r close parenthesis raised to the power t minus one close parenthesis divided by r close bracket
S11_D0_FX_C9.rule_of_72: Rule of 72: Money doubles every ~{doublingTime} years

S11.S11_D1_FX_C2: Let me calculate this using the compound interest calculator. If we invest $50 weekly at 8% annual return, what will be the final return after 10 years?
S11.S11_D2_FX_C1: That's $39,638 after 10 years! And that's just from investing $50 weekly.
S11.S11_D3_FX_C2:
The math behind this is the compound interest formula for regular payments: A = P (1 + r)t + PMT × [
(1 + r)t - 1
r
], here PMT is our weekly payment, r is the weekly interest rate, and t is the number of weeks.
S11.S11_D4_FX_C1: What about different return rates? Dad says the stock market averages 10% historically. How much would our $50 weekly investment be worth after 10 years at 10% instead of 8%?
S11.S11_D5_FX_C2: At 10%, that becomes $44,383 - that is $4,745 more! The compound growth really adds up.
S11.S11_D7_FX_C2: It's the historical average, but it fluctuates significantly year-to-year. Let's use 8% for conservative planning. Also, while our business might grow faster than 8% now, we don't know if that will continue forever.
S11.S11_D8_FX_C1: I'm curious - what if we could invest twice as much? What happens if we invest $100 weekly instead of $50, still at 8% for 10 years?
S11.S11_D9_FX_C2: That would be $79,277 - that's almost exactly double of our initial investment! So doubling our investment doubles our result.
S11.S11_D10_FX_C1: This makes so much sense! We could have both a successful business AND a solid investment portfolio working for us simultaneously.
S11.S11_D11_FX_C2: Exactly. We're using the same exponential growth principles that make our business successful but applying them to wealth building.

S14.S14_D1_FX_C2: The math clearly indicates we're better off without external financing. The exponential function is on our side if we maintain patience and consistency.
S14.S14_D2_FX_C1: I'm actually glad Mr. Donovan rejected us.
S14.S14_D3_FX_C2: Why would you be pleased with a negative outcome?
S14.S14_D4_FX_C1: Because now we know we don't need a bank. The math is on our side.
S14.S14_D5_FX_C2: Time and compound growth - far superior to any loan product on the market.
S14.S14_D6_FX_C1: I can't wait to show Mr. Donovan our millionaire calculator in a few years.
S14.S14_D7_FX_C2: He'll find it difficult to believe that a $20 million business empire originated from a $20 investment in a viscoelastic non-Newtonian fluid.

quest_completion.subheading: You have conquered The Exponential Twins: Mastering Growth Patterns
quest_completion.content:
You completed your journey through the Slime Time STEAMQuest!

  • You calculated compound growth rates for business projections
  • You analyzed how exponential functions model business and investment growth
  • You evaluated the risks of high-interest debt using exponential models
  • You designed a mathematical path to financial independence

Your ability to apply exponential functions to real-world financial situations has shown how mathematics can create paths to business success and personal wealth!

compound_interest.definition:
Compound Interest is interest calculated on both the initial principal and the accumulated interest, causing exponential rather than linear growth. The formula is:
A = P (1 + r)t + PMT √ó [
(1 + r)t ‚àí 1
r
]
Where:
A = Final amount
P = Principal
r = Annual interest rate
t = Time in years

compound_interest_formula.definition:
Compound Interest Formula is a formula used to calculate the growth of an investment over time, based on the principle of compound interest. The formula is:
A = P (1 + r)t + PMT √ó [
(1 + r)t ‚àí 1
r
]
Where:
A = Final amount
P = Principal
r = Annual interest rate
t = Time in years

exponential_growth.definition: Exponential Growth is a pattern of growth where the rate of increase becomes increasingly rapid over time, following a constant multiplier.

annual_percentage_rate.definition: Annual Percentage Rate (APR) is the yearly interest rate charged on borrowed money, including fees and costs related to the loan.

apr.definition: Annual Percentage Rate (APR) is the yearly interest rate charged on borrowed money, including fees and costs related to the loan.

concentration_risk.definition: Concentration Risk is the potential for increased losses when investments are not diversified and are concentrated in a single business or sector.

growth_rate.definition:
Growth Rate is the percentage increase in a value over a specific time period, often calculated using the formula:
r = (R‚ÇÅ ‚ÅÑ R‚ÇÄ)(1 ‚ÅÑ t) ‚àí 1
Where:
r = Growth rate (expressed as a decimal)
R‚ÇÅ = Final value
R‚ÇÄ = Initial value
t = Number of time periods

growth_rates.definition:
Growth Rate is the percentage increase in a value over a specific time period, often calculated using the formula:
r = (R‚ÇÅ ‚ÅÑ R‚ÇÄ)(1 ‚ÅÑ t) ‚àí 1
Where:
r = Growth rate (expressed as a decimal)
R‚ÇÅ = Final value
R‚ÇÄ = Initial value
t = Number of time periods

portfolio_diversification.definition: Portfolio Diversification is the strategy of spreading investments across different assets to reduce risk and potentially increase returns.

conversion_rate.definition: Conversion Rate is the percentage of viewers or visitors who take a desired action (like making a purchase).

conversion_rates.definition: Conversion Rate is the percentage of viewers or visitors who take a desired action (like making a purchase).

minimum_payment.definition: Minimum Payment is the smallest amount a credit card company will accept toward the balance owed each month.

borax_solution.definition: Borax solution is a mixture of borax (sodium borate) powder dissolved in water, commonly used as a key ingredient in homemade slime recipes. Borax acts as a cross-linking agent that transforms liquid glue into the stretchy, elastic polymer structure characteristic of slime.

pmt.definition: PMTis a financial term representing the regular, fixed payment amount made at consistent intervals in financial calculations, particularly in compound interest, loan, and annuity formulas.

return.definition: Return refers to the gain or profit earned on an investment over time.

common.samantha_description: Young woman with glasses wearing "Slime Time" shirt holding tablet.
common.ben_description: Young boy with curly hair wearing "Slime Time" shirt holding tablet.
common.donovan_description: Professional man in dark suit with glasses holding tablet.
common.bg1_description: Suburban neighborhood with houses, white picket fences, and large tree.
common.bg2_description: Modern office with wooden desk, bookshelves, plants, and large windows.
common.bg3_description: Workshop basement with shelves, workbench, tools, and exposed ceiling beams.
common.bg4_description: Storage room with cardboard boxes, shelving, whiteboard, and blue couch.
common.bg5_description: Backyard party with children, slime table, decorations, and string lights.
common.invalid_pair: Invalid Pair! Try a different combination of angles
common.focusModeAnnouncement: Please toggle to focus mode to select angles and drop them in the correct locations.
